inlineContent.text: The lighting model implemented by

is identical to the lighting model implemented in OpenGL ES 1.1; each light interacts with any material properties on the effect to determine the intensity and color that particular light contributes to the scene at a fragment.
There are three basic kinds of lights: directional, point and spotlights.
A directional light is considered to be infinitely far away, and always directs light in the same direction. To create a directional light, set the
property to a vector whose
, and
components specify the direction to the light (that is, the negation of the direction the light is travelling in), and whose
component is set to
A point light is placed at a position within the scene, and emits light in all directions. To create a directional light, set the
property to a vector whose
and
components specify the homogenous coordinates for the position of the light in the scene. The
component is typically set to
and must not be set to
The intensity of a point light is adjusted using an distance attenuation function. This function is controlled by adjusting the
or
properties. The default values for these properties create a light whose intensity is constant over distance.
A spotlight is placed at a position within the scene, and emits light in a specific direction in a cone. To create a spotlight, set the
property to a vector whose
and
components specify the homogenous coordinates for the position of the light in the scene. The
component must not be set to
. Then, set the
property to a vector that specifies the direction of the light and the
to a value less than
Like a point light, a spotlight’s intensity can be adjusted using the distance attenuation properties. A spotlight’s intensity can also be changed as a function of the spotlight angle by setting the

property. The default value for a spotlight creates a spotlight whose intensity is not affected by the angle. That is, the spotlight radiates the same amount of light at the center and at the edge of the cone.

Lighting calculations are performed in eye-space coordinates.  The eye-space coordinates for the position and the spot direction are calculated at the precise moment that new position values are specified and may be affected by other properties of the effect. For more information, see

abstract.text: Speed up OpenGL ES or OpenGL app development. Use math libraries, background texture loading, pre-created shader effects, and a standard view and view controller to implement your rendering loop.
A simple lighting and shading system for use in shader-based OpenGL rendering.
The abstract superclass for configuration information used in GLKit rendering effects.
Fog drawing information for use in GLKit rendering effects.
Lighting information for use in GLKit rendering effects.
The ambient portion of the light.
A constant factor applied to the attenuation of a point light or spotlight.
The diffuse portion of the light.
A Boolean value that indicates whether calculations should be performed on this light.
A linear factor applied to the attenuation of a point light or spotlight.
The position of the light in world coordinates.
A quadratic factor applied to the attenuation of a point light or spotlight.
The specular portion of the light.
The angle in degrees where the spotlight is cut off.
A vector indicating the direction the spotlight is projecting.
A value indicating how focused the spotlight is.
A transform applied to the light’s position and direction before calculating the contribution of the light.
Surface appearance properties for use in GLKit rendering effects.
Texture drawing parameters for use in GLKit rendering effects.
Coordinate transform information for use in GLKit rendering effects.
A constant that describes how lighting is calculated by an effect.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
